Next‐turn strategy: once on (2,9), if (3,9) is still occupied by the enemy’s tail I can drop down to (2,8) and then weave back up toward those apples.  

My move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
I’m at (2,6) and my immediate options are:

• UP → (2,7) is my own body (dead).  
• LEFT → (1,6) is empty but no apple and doesn’t improve my position.  
• RIGHT → (3,6) is empty but steers me away from the nearest apple.  
• DOWN → (2,5) is empty and on the straight line to the apple at (2,4).

Moving DOWN keeps me safe, avoids head‐to‐head risks, and gets me two moves away from the apple at (2,4).  
Next‐turn plan: go DOWN again to eat that apple, then head east toward the apple at (6,4).

DOWN

0.rationale:
Let’s enumerate my options from (2,9):

- UP → (2,10) is off‐board, instant death.  
- DOWN → (2,8) is occupied by snake #1’s body, death.  
- LEFT → (1,9) is my own body, death.  
- RIGHT → (3,9) is currently snake #1’s body segment—if I step there now I’ll die as well.  

In fact, every direct neighbor is occupied, so I’m trapped. The only hope would be if, by the time I move, that segment at (3,9) has been vacated by snake #1’s tail shifting—but given its body layout it won’t free up (3,9) on the very next turn. In short, no truly safe move exists and I’m going to collide no matter what.

Given I was already committed to “pushing” toward the apples on the right, I’ll go RIGHT again.

Next‐turn strategy (if by miracle (3,9) is clear): from (3,9) drop down to (3,8) or swing back through (2,8) and weave toward (7,9).

My move: RIGHT

1.rationale:
Let’s survey from (2,5):

- UP → (2,6) is my own body (death).  
- LEFT → (1,5) is empty but steers away from the nearest apple.  
- RIGHT → (3,5) is empty but also away from the apple.  
- DOWN → (2,4) has an apple.  

Going DOWN eats the apple at (2,4), is safe, and keeps me on course. Next turn I’ll head east along y=4 toward the apple at (6,4).
